poem:
### Waiting in Gaza

Dust laces the air  
with whispered fears, cold  
as the stone hearts  
from which ceasefires are carved.  
  
Eyes, unblinking in the dark,  
await the brittle *click*  
of promised peace only to find  
swords unsheathed anew.  
  
In silence, a prayer hangs,  
hope braided with dread,  
while the world watches,  
deaf as ever.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘We will be betrayed’: cold, fearful and still under fire, Gaza’s people wait Amid continuing airstrikes, bitter cold and news of delays, millions in Gaza were waiting anxiously on Thursday for confirmation that the ceasefire-for-hostages deal between Hamas and Israel was going ahead. Many spoke of their fear that hopes of a new beginning after a 15-month conflict might be dashed. The war has killed many tens of thousands in the territory and reduced swathes". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
